title: is "more preferred" correct? | WordReference Forums
text: Context and the actual sentence make a difference. In your sentence, "more preferred" is unnecessary and even wrong, but as I said, it could work in other sentences. "More preferred" suggests that out of multiple preferred things, there's a stronger preference for one.but sometimes I read sentences with "more preferred" and I was confused. Based on that, in written language, I think "more preferred" should be avoided.
